title: C90-3063

sentences.text: Manual acquisition of semantic constraints in broad domains is very expensive .
This paper presents an automatic scheme for collecting statistics on cooccurrence patterns in a large corpus .
To a large extent , these statistics reflect semantic constraints and thus are used to disambiguate anaphora references and syntactic ambiguities .
The scheme was implemented by gathering statistics on the output of other linguistic tools .
An experiment was performed to resolve references of the pronoun `` it '' in sentences that were randomly selected from the corpus .
The results of the experiment show that in most of the cases the cooccurrence statistics indeed reflect the semantic constraints and thus provide a basis for a useful disambiguation tool .

summary: Manual acquisition of semantic constraints in broad domains is very expensive . This paper presents an automatic scheme for collecting statistics on cooccurrence patterns in a large corpus . To a large extent , these statistics reflect semantic constraints and thus are used to disambiguate anaphora references and syntactic ambiguities . The scheme was implemented by gathering statistics on the output of other linguistic tools . An experiment was performed to resolve references of the pronoun `` it '' in sentences that were randomly selected from the corpus . The results of the experiment show that in most of the cases the cooccurrence statistics indeed reflect the semantic constraints and thus provide a basis for a useful disambiguation tool .

Predicate-acquires.label: acquires
Predicate-acquires.description: To acquire means to obtain or gain possession of something, often through effort, learning, or experience. The subject of the predicate 'acquires' takes on a new understanding, skill, or knowledge by engaging with the object, which represents the thing being acquired.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: To present something means to introduce or offer it as a solution, idea, or representation. In this sense, the predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject (e.g., an author, researcher) offers or provides the object (e.g., a scheme, method, concept), making it available for consideration, discussion, or application.

Predicate-reflect.label: reflect
Predicate-reflect.description: To reflect means to consider or think about something in relation to a particular context or framework. It implies considering the subject's perspective or characteristics as relevant to understanding the object. In general, 'reflect' connects the subject and object by suggesting that the subject's properties or attributes are being used to inform our comprehension of the object.

Predicate-was_performed_to_resolve_refer.label: was performed to resolve references of
Predicate-was_performed_to_resolve_refer.description: This predicate indicates that an action (the subject) aimed to clarify or identify specific references (object), likely involving ambiguity resolution. The connection between the subject and object suggests a causal relationship, where the performance of the action was intended to resolve uncertainty or confusion related to the referenced entities.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that an action or state exists at a current point in time. It suggests that something is happening now, and it connects the subject to the object by implying that the subject has brought about or contributed to the existence of the described situation.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general category, concept, or class represented by the object.
